School of Rare Earths, University of Science and Technology of China Hefei 230026 China. Catalytic vapor-phase dehydration of glycerol is an energy-efficient and environmentally friendly route for producing acrolein, a valuable organic chemical intermediate. However, anti-coking is one of the key problems due to the excessively acid catalytic sites and sluggish mass transfer, restricting the industrial application of this reaction. Herein, potassium element modified BPO4 monolithic foams with the hierarchically porous structure were synthesized by adding potassium element in the gel precursor of BPO4. The catalyst introducing 3% K exhibited the best acrolein selectivity of 81.0% with nearly complete glycerol conversion. In a 10-hour run of the reaction at 320 °C, the selectivity of acrolein could remain at 75.9% with 94.5% glycerol conversion, indicating the superior stability. The excellent activity and stability for 3% K-BPO4 is mainly attributed to the synergetic effect between hierarchical structure providing favorable mass transfer and appropriate acid catalytic sites inhibiting over dehydration reaction. They not only boost activity but also reduce coking, providing a unique approach for the design of solid acid catalyst. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Porous foam structure Potassium modification Glycerol dehydration Anti-coking Stability Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Biomass energy, as a high-efficiency green energy, is playing an increasingly important role in our energy industry and has attracted more and more attention from society, among which biofuels have the great potential to be used as substitutes or additives for traditional fossil fuels [1,2]. In the past decade, the researches on transesterification of vegetable fat, animal fat or waste fat with methanol to produce biodiesel have flourished [3,4]. However, during the industrial synthesis process, whether catalyzed by acids, bases, or enzymes, a large amount of by-product will be inevitably generated [5–8]. With the active deepening of studies on biodiesel and the accretion of production scale in successive years, the output of crude glycerol is also increasing year by year, making its transformation and utilization an urgent problem to be solved [9,10]. Making full use of crude glycerol will greatly improve the economic feasibility of diesel production, accordingly, it is of great practical significance to undertake investigation on converting glycerol into high value-added chemicals [11–14]. One of the most promising transformation pathways of glycerol is catalytic dehydration to synthesize acrolein, which is a momentous fine industrial intermediate in the chemical and agricultural industries. The current researches that have been extensively conducted on the preparation of acrolein by selective gas-phase dehydration of aqueous glycerol center on solid acid catalysts [15,16]. Tao et al. [17] explored and compared a great variety of solid acids and bases for this reaction, among which solid acids with acid strength in the range of − 8.2 < H0 ≤ −3.0 (H0 is the Hammett acidity function), i.e. moderately strong acids, were identified to exhibit the best catalytic performance. The introduction of alkali metal can affect acidity, on the one hand due to changes caused by alkali metal doping [18,19], and on the other hand owing to the formation of other species [20,21]. Furthermore, carbon deposits are inevitable in the reaction, which lead to not only deactivation of catalysts, but also a decrease in the selectivity for the target products, thereby reducing the lifetime of the catalyst [22,23]. The formation of coke increases with the increment of acid strength and amount, proving that the acidic sites are the active sites for coking [24,25]. Carbon deposition is also related to the diffusion resistance of the catalyst, and it is generally believed that coke is easily generated under diffusion limiting conditions [26–28]. Therefore, a reasonable design of catalyst to balance activity and anti-coking for the dehydration of glycerol to acrolein is the key challenge. Boron phosphate, due to its own series of interesting properties and outstanding performance, has been mainly served as an organic synthesis catalyst [29–31], flame retardant [32–34], ceramic material [35], phosphor powder [36–38], and composite membrane in fuel cell [39–42]. It is worth noting that BPO4 has excellent thermal stability and environmental friendliness, with a large number of Brönsted and Lewis acid sites which are easy to activate and regenerate. Therefore, BPO4 has been used as an efficient solid acid catalyst [43,44]. However, the synthesis of BPO4 from phosphoric acid and boric acid generally requires calcination at high temperature to crystallize, tending to form bulky solids with few or even no pores and inducing extremely low specific surface area, which is usually not conducive to catalytic reactions. Liu et al. [45] developed macroscopic foams with hierarchically porous structure obtained from viscous gel precursors via a one-step annealing process. The monolithic BPO4 foam material with large specific surface area and porosity has a self-supporting framework of BPO4 hollow spheres, whose active sites can be fully exposed resulting from its distinctive structure. In this work, inspired by the synthesis method of monolithic foams, we prepared modified BPO4 catalysts by adding potassium salt to adjust the acidity of the catalyst, followed by testing the potential of the materials in gas-phase dehydration of glycerol to acrolein. The conversion of glycerol, selectivity of acrolein and the catalytic stability was studied and boosted by virtue of hierarchical structure and the adjustable acid property. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis 2.1.1 Preparation of monolithic BPO4 foam 2.00 g Boric acid (H3BO3, AR) and 2.12 g diammonium hydrogen phosphate ((NH4)2HPO4, AR) purchased from Shanghai Hushi Co., Ltd. were dissolved in 20 mL ultrapure water with stirring in a ceramic crucible. Sticky hydrogel appeared in the wake of the evaporation of water at 120 °C and was immediately transferred into a muffle furnace. The precursor was calcined at 750 °C with the heating rate of 5 °C/min for 2 h in air. After natural cooling, the white macroscopic B2O3 @BPO4 foam was obtained (Scheme S1). The product was afterwards divided into small pieces and immersed in excessive methanol (CH3OH, AR, Xilong Scientific Co., Ltd.), followed by static evaporation to dryness at 80 °C to remove the boron oxide nanowires on the surface. Finally, the white BPO4 foam was gained. 2.1.2 Preparation of monolithic foam modified with potassium salt Different amounts of potassium nitrate (KNO3, AR, Xilong Scientific Co., Ltd.) were added into the initial solution of H3BO3 and (NH4)2HPO4 (potassium element content compared to the mass of produced BPO4 without adding potassium nitrate), which is shown in Scheme 1. The following experimental operations were the same as the above synthesis process. It is worth noting that with the increase of potassium addition, the degree of expansion of the foams decreased in turn. When introducing 15% K, the foam structure was completely lost and the product clung to the inner wall of the ceramic crucible, so the subsequent treatment, characterization and activity test were not carried out. The final materials were denoted as 1% K-BPO4, 3% K-BPO4, 5% K-BPO4, and 10% K-BPO4, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were measured from 2θ = 5–80° in 10 min on a D8 Advance equipment from Bruker AXS Co., Ltd. BET data of the catalysts were collected by liquid nitrogen physical adsorption-desorption method in a relative pressure range of P/P0 = 0–1.0 on a Kubo-1200 ultra high-speed specific surface area analyzer. The samples required vacuum degassing pretreatment at 300 °C, 2.6 × 10-3 kPa for 3 h to remove gas impurities adsorbed on the surface prior to the measurement. The acidity of the catalysts was analyzed by temperature-programmed desorption of NH3, and the experiments were conducted on a Autochem II 2920 chemisorption analyzer produced by Micromeritics Instruments Co., Ltd. 0.15 g catalysts were pretreated for degasification at 200 °C with 10 °C/min in a He flow of 30 mL/min for 1 h and the reactor was cooled to 50 °C to adsorb NH3 for 60 min in a 10% NH3/He flow (30 mL/min) to ensure saturation. The samples were then purged with a He flow for 1 h to remove physically adsorbed NH3. Finally, the measurements were carried out at 600 °C at the heating rate of 10 °C/min in the presence of He, and the curves of the desorbed NH3 signal versus temperature were detected by TCD. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectral analysis was completed on the Nicolet is50 in-situ infrared spectrometer from Thermo Fisher Scientific, U. S. A. with the wavenumber resolution of 4 cm-1. The cycling scanning was performed for 32 times in the scanning wavenumber range of 4000–400 cm-1. Pyridine adsorbed infrared (Py-IR) experiments were run on the same instrument as regular infrared spectral analysis. The samples were pretreated in vacuum at 350 °C for 1 h and then cooled to 30 °C to measure the background spectra. After that, pyridine adsorption was carried out at 30 °C for 1 h, followed by vacuum desorption with the spectra recorded at different target temperatures. In situ DRIFTs were also recorded on the Nicolet is50 spectrometer from 1800 to 1300 cm-1. The catalyst was pretreated at 300 °C for 30 min under an Ar flow and the DRIFTs cell was then cooled to 100 °C to detect the background spectra. Then, glycerol was heated through the oil bath at 120 °C and the vapor was admitted to the cell under an Ar flow of 30 mL/min. The spectra were obtained at intervals of 50 °C between 100 and 300 °C, with each temperature point lasting for 15 min. The temperature-programmed oxidation tests were performed on a HPR20 mass spectrometer detector by detecting the generated CO2 signal. 0.03 g samples after the dehydration reaction were pretreated with a O2 flow (30 mL/min) for 30 min to remove adsorbed CO2, and then the temperature dependent data were measured at 800 °C with 10 °C/min under O2 atmosphere. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy was collected on an ESCALAB Xi+ X-ray photoelectron spectrometer, using Al Kα radiation with an energy of 1486.6 eV as the excitation source. C 1 s binding energy (284.6 eV) as the standard was used to calibrate the binding energy of all elements. The peaks of O 1 s were fixed at 532.4 eV, 533.0 eV, and 533.9 eV, respectively. The FWHM of B 1 s was fixed at 2.3 eV. The peak spacing of P 2p1/2 and P 2p3/2 was fixed at 0.9 eV, and the peak area ratio was fixed at 0.51:1. The peak spacing of K 2p1/2 and K 2p3/2 was fixed at 2.8 eV, and the peak area ratio was fixed at 0.51:1. JSM-IT800 high resolution field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM) was employed to observe the surface morphology and structural characteristics of the catalysts. The samples were ground into powder and evenly spread on conductive adhesive. F200 high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) was employed to investigate the fine structure of the catalysts. The samples were ground into powder and dispersed ultrasonically in ethanol for 30 min 2.3 Catalytic performance Vapor-phase dehydration of glycerol was carried out on a vertical fixed-bed reactor equipped with quartz tubes (i.d. 8 mm, length 50 cm) at 320 °C under atmospheric pressure. A thermocouple was used to monitor the temperature of the reactor. A constant amount of catalyst was sandwiched by quartz sand and quartz wool in the middle of the reactor. The quartz sand was loaded above the catalyst to ensure that the reactants could be completely vaporized. Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was heated to 350 °C and kept for 1 h in flowing high-purity nitrogen (40 mL/min). After the reactor was cooled down to 320 °C, the 10.02 wt% aqueous solution of glycerol (CHOH(CH2OH)2, purity＞99.5% (GC), Shanghai Aladdin Chemistry Co., Ltd.) was continuously fed into the quartz tube through a micro-infusion pump at the feed rate of 0.050 mL/min and high-purity N2 (40 mL/min) was used as carrier gas. The liquid products were condensed in 3 glass containers with 5 mL methanol connected in series through silicone tubes in the ice-brine bath and collected every 2 h for off-line analysis by a GC-2060 assembled with a KB-1301 capillary column (30 m × 0.32 mm×1.00 µm) and a flame ionization detector. 0.1 mL n-butanol (CH3(CH2)3OH, purity＞99.9% (HPLC), Beijing Innochem Science & Technology Co., Ltd.) was served as an internal standard to facilitate quantification. The condensed products during the initial 30 min of the reaction were discarded due to temperature instability and poor material balance. The conversion of glycerol and selectivity of the main products were calculated based on the formulas below: (1) Conversion % = Moles of glycerol in the feed − Moles of glycerol unreacted Moles of glycerol in the feed × 100 (2) Selectivity ( % ) = Moles of carbon in a product defined Moles of carbon in glycerol consumed × 100 2.4 Activation energy test The activation energy was also measured on the fixed-bed reactor. The gas compositions remained the same as those in the vapor-phase dehydration performance test. Testing temperature was set from 290 °C to 320 °C, and the experiments were conducted every 10 °C with recording the conversion of glycerol. In addition, for all these catalysts, in order to eliminate the impacts of external and internal diffusion, the glycerol conversion was required to be controlled below 20% by adjusting the weight hourly space velocity. The Mears and Weiz-Prater criterium were used to check the diffusion limitation [46,47] and the results are listed in the Supplementary Materials. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of composition and structure The effect of K modification on the crystal form structure of catalysts was investigated by the X-ray powder diffraction test and the results were displayed in Fig. 1a. All synthesized samples exhibited distinct diffractions peaks at 2θ = 24.5°, 39.9°, 48.8°, 50.1°, 63.7° and 71.4°, respectively, in agreement with those of the standard card of boron phosphate (PDF #34–0132) [48], of which the diffraction peak at 2θ = 24.5° is the strongest, corresponding to the (1 0 1) crystal plane. As the addition amount increased, the diffraction peaks associated with BPO4 of the catalysts shifted slightly towards a larger angle, possibly due to the occupation of multiple lattice sites or the resulting changes in electronegativity by doped potassium. Simultaneously, the intensity gradually attenuated, revealing that potassium element modification led to the diminishment in the content of BPO4. However, there was not much difference in the FT-IR spectra of different catalysts (Fig. S1). Introducing 3–10% K brought about appearance of the characteristic X-ray diffraction peaks of tetragonal KH2PO4 crystal structure (PDF #79–0585) at 2θ = 17.4°, 23.8°, 30.7°, 34.0° and 46.4°, which implied the reaction between KNO3 and (NH4)2HPO4. In contrast, when adding as low as 1%, there were no typical diffraction peaks of K species in the XRD pattern, which may be attributed to the highly dispersion of KH2PO4 present in the 1% K-BPO4 sample. Moreover, all samples showed no signals for boron oxide, implying that B2O3 covering the surface of the boron phosphate spheres was substantially removed by the esterification reaction with methanol. Figs. 1b and S2 illustrate the XPS spectra of O 1 s spectra, survey spectra, B 1 s + P 2 s spectra, P 2p spectra, and K 2p spectra, respectively. The increment of potassium introduction could be observed through the obviously continuous increase in XRD peak intensity of KH2PO4 in Fig. 1a and the oxygen peak intensity near 532.4 eV attributed to the P-O-K bond [49] in KH2PO4 of all modified catalysts obtained from XPS tests in Fig. 1b, which demonstrated that the higher contents of potassium introduced led to significant formation and growth of the tetragonal crystallites of KH2PO4. As shown in Table S1, the P/B atomic ratio ranged from 0.326 to 0.338, with an overall increase, indicating a certain loss of B. BET results are important components of the evaluation indicators for catalyst properties. It can be clearly observed from Fig. S3 that the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the catalysts exhibited a mixture of type II and III [50], indicating the structure dominated by macropores. As shown in Fig. S4, the synthesized catalysts are hierarchically porous materials with both smaller and larger mesopores, and the wide peak shape manifested that the pore diameter distribution was nonuniform. Compared with the unmodified material, the pore distribution of 1–5% K-BPO4 had a little change (10–30 nm), and there were likely some micropores in 1% K-BPO4 and 3% K-BPO4, which illustrated that the structure would be subjected to minimal influence when adding less potassium. It can be also seen from Fig. S4e that the pore diameter of 10% K-BPO4 was chiefly distributed in smaller mesopores (3–6 nm), manifesting that the main structure would be damaged under excessive introduction, especially for large mesopores. Except for 10% K-BPO4, the specific surface area of all other catalysts was greater than that of the reported integral B2O3 @BPO4 foam (10.1 m2/g) [45], which might be the result of lower calcination temperature. It can be concluded that moderate potassium addition didn’t significantly improve the specific surface area of materials, but the maximum BET surface area was 26.1 m2/g under 3% K modification which was derived from the effect of small pores generated; while the BET surface area and total pore volume tremendously diminished under excessive addition, owing to the destruction of the frame (Fig. S5h) and the great loss of pores, which meant that the porosity was small and adsorption performance was poor. The SEM images in Figs. 2a and S5 display the rough morphology of 3% K-BPO4 and other synthesized catalysts, respectively. Even after the products in Scheme 1 and S1 were divided into small pieces and treated with methanol, it is evident from Figs. 2a and S5a-d that there were foam walls with different thicknesses formed by considerable quantities of clearly visible boron phosphate spheres stacked tightly in the structure of the synthesized BPO4 and catalysts modified with 1% and 3% K, which were relatively uniform in size at the nanoscale, revealing why the self-supporting monolithic foam materials could be made up. It is worth noting that there were numerous pores with diameters of nanometer and micrometer on the foam walls, which were separated by the packing of BPO4 spheres, leading to the gradient hierarchically porous structure [45]. Therefore, the appropriate addition of potassium wouldn’t affect the macroscopically highly foamy frame and microscopically hierarchical pore structure. Moreover, the addition of 3% K affected the growth of BPO4 grains, resulting in a decrease in particle size and a change in the packing situation, leading to an increase in the number of small pores (Fig. S4c), which explained the improvement of specific surface area. However, as shown in Fig. S5g, the large rod-shaped structure appeared, with the formation of bowl-like structure due to rupture of partial spheres resulting in the heterogeneity of the distribution of nanospheres, which indicated that 5% K modification caused certain damage to the overall frame. Fig. S5h clearly demonstrates that after introducing 10% K, the main structure was ruined to a great extent and the small pores separated by the stacking of nanospheres basically disappeared, with masses of bulky-sized blocky particles on the surface, which was in agreement with the diminishment of larger mesopores and BET surface area (Fig. S4e and Table 1). Based on the above results, the structurally controllable materials are conducive to mass transfer. In order to better understand the influence of K species on the formation of catalyst structure and observe the approximate distribution of P, O, K, and B elements in the selected region, 10% K-BPO4, the catalyst with the most apparent structural damage, subsequently served as the research object for the SEM energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy test. Fig. S6a-e exhibits that, consistent with the above analysis, most of the structure was destroyed, with considerably thick sheets derived from the K species interspersed therein, and various elements evenly distributed in the corresponding regions, which confirmed that the initially added KNO3 reacted with (NH4)2HPO4 instead of H3BO3. KNO3 was in competition with H3BO3 in the preparation reaction, consuming a portion of (NH4)2HPO4, changing the internal environment of solution and hydrogel precursor. 3% K-BPO4, with the optimal various structural characteristics, was characterized by transmission electron microscopy. The microstructure of the sample consisted of many spheres with the external irregular convex (Figs. 2b and S7a) and internal hollow structure which possessed the particle diameter of hundreds of nanometers (Figs. 2c and S7b), where boron oxide nanowires weren’t observed on the surface [51], consistent with the XRD analysis (Fig. 1), demonstrating the thorough removal of B2O3. HRTEM image (Fig. 2d) of the synthesized 3% K-BPO4 catalyst at the plotting scale of 2 nm distinctly exhibited two regular lattice fringes of different crystal planes, which fully complied with the spacing of main lattice fringes of BPO4 by comparing with the standard PDF card of the substance identified by JADE software, coinciding with the (1 0 1) crystal plane with the spacing of d = 0.364 nm and the (1 1 2) crystal plane with the spacing of d = 0.225 nm, respectively. The electron diffraction pattern (Fig. 2e) revealed the characteristic of polycrystal, that is, the formation of multiple concentric ring diffraction lines, which also corresponded to the (1 0 1) and (1 1 2) crystal planes of BPO4. Furthermore, the TEM mapping images of hollow spheres showed the uniform distribution of P, O, K, and B elements in the hollow nanospheres (Fig. 2f-j). It seems that the distribution of K was independent of other elements, which was considered to replace partial original positions of B element. Briefly, combined with the SEM and TEM images, the distinctive hierarchical structure of the monolithic foam is exhibited in Fig. 2k, which can be seen that the self-supporting foam with hollow sphere structure was realized through foam walls formed by numerous spheres stacked tightly, containing multimodal pore-like structure from nanometer to millimeter scale. The foams have high BET surface area (Table 1) with multiple pores such as mesopores and even micropores (Fig. S4c), indicating that it retained the large specific surface area of hollow spheres, probably owing to the unique packing structure of hollow spheres. 3.2 Catalytic performance in the gas-phase dehydration of glycerol The catalytic performance in the dehydration of glycerol (TOS = 2 h) is displayed in Fig. 3a. It can be seen clearly that BPO4, the bare catalyst, exhibited the best catalytic activity and 100% glycerol was converted. For the modified catalysts, the catalytic activity slightly reduced, and the glycerol conversion decreased sequentially as the addition of potassium element increased, but both were higher than 97%. The selectivity of acrolein presented a tendency which elevated firstly and then declined with the increase of potassium introduction, of which the 3% K-BPO4 catalyst gave the maximum selectivity for acrolein (81.0%). However, there was little distinction in the selectivity of hydroxyacetone among different catalysts in general, obtaining the highest (15.7%) in the catalytic reaction of BPO4, but the lowest (12.3%) on 10% K-BPO4. It can be concluded that the total selectivity of the two main products showed the best (94.6%) when modified with 3% K, while introducing 10% K resulted in the apparent reduction, which probably was the consequence of structural changes of the catalyst shown in Figs. S4e and S5h. According to the results of dehydration reaction, 3% K-BPO4 had the best comprehensive catalytic performance. After catalyzing the gas-phase dehydration reaction of glycerol, the coke was inevitably generated on the surface of boron phosphate with different contents of potassium introduced. Therefore, the carbon deposition amount of partial recovered catalysts was analyzed and characterized by the TPO testing under O2 atmosphere. The raw results are shown in Fig. 3b, where the x-axis is the test temperature and the y-axis is the signal value of CO2, with the integral of the curve representing the relative total amount of CO2. It can be distinctly seen that for the coke on the surface of these catalysts after reaction, it mainly reacted with O2 between 200–400 °C and 400–700 °C to produce CO2. CO2 generated between 200–400 °C was attributed to some “soft carbon” species - organic residues and coke that were prone to oxidation, such as amorphous organic compounds with high hydrogen content, while that between 400–700 °C was principally due to the oxidation of some “hard carbon” species - polymers with low hydrogen content. The difference in H content between two carbonaceous species can be demonstrated by the formation of H2O in TPO testing (Fig. S8). The temperature variant curves of 1% K-BPO4 and 3% K-BPO4 samples after participating in the dehydration reaction suggest that compared with BPO4, 1% and 3% potassium modification led to the significant reduction of the amount of CO2 generated by oxidation of carbon deposits in the range of 200–700 °C. When reaching to 5%, the rise in peak intensity near 250 °C, 340 °C and 500 °C to a certain content indicated the increment of the amount of the coke formed in the reaction. However, for the 10% K-BPO4 catalyst, the insoluble carbonaceous materials deposited on the surface, especially the “hard carbon” species, increased greatly during the gas-phase dehydration reaction of glycerol compared with all other catalysts, which also matched the results of the performance test (Fig. 3a). To sum up, introducing moderate potassium could appropriately inhibit the formation of the coke and as the addition amount gradually increased, the insoluble carbonaceous species deposited were more likely to produce. Among all these catalysts, 3% K-BPO4 exhibited the most excellent effect in resisting carbon deposition. Subsequently, the TPO measurement was conducted using external carbon to specify the quantification of coke amount and obtain carbon balance data. 0.01 g carbon black was mixed evenly with 0.10 g quartz sand (100–120 mesh), and 0.03 g mixed sample was taken for O2-TPO experiment with the same testing methods. The obtained results are shown in Fig. 3a. It can be clearly seen that the carbon balance was below 100%, owing to the presence of a little coke on the inner wall of the quartz tube from the catalytic reactor and other undefined side reactions. The kinetic investigation was conducted on three catalysts, BPO4, 3% K-BPO4 and 10% K-BPO4, to further reveal the reasons for the differences in catalytic performance in dehydration reactions. As shown in Fig. 3c, among these three catalysts, the apparent activation energy on 3% K-BPO4 (48.6 kJ/mol) during the catalytic process was the lowest, which was slightly lower than that on BPO4 (49.3 kJ/mol) and far below that on 10% K-BPO4 (68.8 kJ/mol), suggesting that the gas-phase dehydration of glycerol was more difficult to proceed on the surface of 10% K-BPO4, which should be a result of structural changes. Due to the optimal overall performance of the 3% K-BPO4 catalyst, the catalytic stability of the sample was evaluated and the glycerol conversion during the test and the selectivity of acrolein and hydroxyacetone with time are presented in Fig. 3d, respectively. It can be noticed that there was only a modest decline in both conversion and selectivity along with the continuous test, which was related to the loss of acidic sites caused by coke on the surface. In addition, it can be seen from Fig. S9 that there was no significant difference in the XRD patterns of the fresh and spent 3% K-BPO4, indicating the relatively good stability of the catalyst structure. Table 2 summarizes the reaction conditions and performance of some catalysts. ZrNbP0.2–1c, H6P2W18O62/MCM-41, HZSM-5%, and 25% W-KIT-6 possessed high BET surface area, which could promote glycerol dehydration to some extent. Among them, H6P2W18O62/MCM-41 showed moderate acidity and acid strength, while the other three catalysts owned strong acid sites with the higher total acid amount, explaining less coke formed on the H6P2W18O62/MCM-41 catalyst surface. The catalysts exhibited the fast deactivation rate, possibly due to the leaching of H6P2W18O62 from MCM-41, as well as the excessive acidity of the others. Accordingly, as shown in Fig. 3d, the acrolein and hydroxyacetone selectivity of 75.9% and 11.8%, respectively, was obtained at 94.5% glycerol conversion even after catalyzing dehydration for 10 h, manifesting the superior stability of 3% K-BPO4 in comparison to the above catalysts. 3.3 Acidity measurement and mechanism exploration It is well known that the gas-phase dehydration reaction of glycerol is carried out under acid catalysis, so the acidity of the catalyst plays a very critical role in the reaction, and the increase of acidic property usually means the improvement of catalytic activity. NH3-TPD is the most common approach for evaluating the acidity of the catalyst, combined with Py-IR test for characterizing the types and relative contents of acid sites on the catalyst surface, including Brönsted acid and Lewis acid. Our original data of NH3-TPD profiles of bare and potassium-modified catalysts are displayed in Fig. 4a and the total acid amount was listed in Table 1. It can be plainly observed from the curves of BPO4 and 1% K-BPO4 that 1% potassium modification had no significant impact on the overall acid strength and amount. The small peak below 100 °C in the 1% K catalyst was likely from incomplete removal of adsorbed NH3 before TPD. As for 3% and 5% K modified catalysts, the peaks around 200 °C became narrower than that of BPO4, indicating a more homogeneous distribution of acidic sites, while the number of strong acid sites also decreased which could be seen by the peak height within the temperature range of 300–600 °C. It can be considered that the changes in acidity were possibly caused by the potassium doping [55,56], revealing the reason for the decrease in glycerol conversion. For 5% K-BPO4, there was an increase in acid content without a visible change in acid strength, leading to an increment in “soft carbon” species, which explained the notable rise in the peak intensity near 250 °C in Fig. 3b. Whereas, compared with the 5% K-modified catalyst, the surprising enhancement in overall acidity and acid amount was obtained through the profile of 10% K-BPO4, which could be speculated to be attributed to the excessive generation of KH2PO4 and its uneven distribution, illuminating the increase in the unknown products and coke (Fig. 3d). As the introduction of potassium gradually increased, the atomic surface ratio between K/B rose (Table S2), which was possibly caused by doped K when the addition amount was below 3%, and by the excessive KH2PO4 generated when it exceeded 3%. Moderate potassium modification could adjust the acid strength and amount on the surface of the bare catalyst, thereby regulating the glycerol dehydration performance. However, excessive addition of potassium not only damaged the structure, but also caused an abnormal change in acidity. The diminishment of BET surface area caused by the destruction of BPO4 spheres and uneven distribution of KH2PO4 was not conducive to the adsorption of reactants and stability of the catalyst in dehydration reaction of glycerol, making it more prone to carbon deposition and accelerating the deactivation rate. Different relative contents of Brönsted acid and Lewis acid may lead to the change of selectivity for the products of glycerol dehydration. The production of acrolein requires the first elimination of the secondary OH group of glycerol to form 1,3-propanediol. Alhanash et al. [57] suggested that the pathway is more advantageous over Brönsted acid sites without the influence of steric constraint as the formed secondary C+ intermediate is more stable than the primary C+, while only the terminal OH group in heteropolyacids can interact with two oxygen-bridged metal atoms derived from Lewis acid sites to form hydroxyacetone due to steric hindrance. However, there was no direct evidence to support this mechanism. Wang et al. [58] investigated the performance of ZSM-5 in gas-phase glycerol dehydration and found that Lewis acid sites are able to synergistically promote the formation of acrolein with Brönsted acid sites. The formation of hydroxyacetone has always been a controversial issue, and Lewis acid sites can transform to Brönsted acid sites in the presence of steam [57,59]. Consequently, Brönsted acid sites are more active for the acrolein formation. Moreover, in the process of producing acrolein, 3-hydroxypropanal intermediate and acrolein are able to undergo polymerization reactions to form cyclic compounds [60]. Although hydroxyacetone is relatively stable, it can still continue to generate furan derivatives. Therefore, carbon deposition may occur on multiple active sites. Fig. 4b shows the Py-IR spectra of BPO4, 3% K-BPO4 and 10% K-BPO4 at 320 °C to distinguish the Brönsted and Lewis acid sites. The PyL absorption peaks represent pyridine absorbed by Lewis acid sites, while the PyB absorption peaks represent pyridine absorbed by Brönsted acid sites. The bands near 1450 and 1610 cm-1 were attributed to the PyL absorption peaks, the bands assigned to the PyB absorption peaks were observed near 1543 and 1637 cm-1, and the band near 1490 cm-1 corresponded to a mixed one of PyL and PyB [61–63]. The structure of BPO4 is composed of alternating and repeating tetrahedrons of BO4 and PO4, whose Brönsted acid sites on the surface are B-OH and P-OH, and Lewis acid sites are derived from P+ (B--O-P+). It can be seen that the Brönsted and Lewis acid content of the catalysts first decreased and then increased with the increment of potassium addition, and the total acid content was also the same, which was consistent with the NH3-TPD results. It is worth noting that the ratio of Brönsted acid to Lewis acid (B/L) in 3% K-BPO4 was lower than that in BPO4, due to the reduction of B-OH and P-OH resulting from potassium doped, revealing why carbon deposition was minimal on 3% K-BPO4. However, acid phosphates are able to provide certain protons that can be used to regulate the acidity of catalysts [64]. Therefore, it is considered that the excessive KH2PO4 played a corresponding role in increasing the Brönsted acid sites in 10% K-BPO4. Based on the above analysis, as shown in Fig. 5, possible reaction mechanism was proposed. To further validate the reaction on the 3% K-BPO4 catalyst, in situ DRIFT testing during the dehydration of glycerol was run. Fig. 4c illustrates the spectra of different carbon species generated from glycerol and simultaneously adsorbed on the 3% K-BPO4 sample at different temperatures. In the experiment, the peak area of the corresponding adsorbed species is directly proportional to its content. As shown in Fig. 4c, three typical bands assigned to glycerol appeared at 1456 cm-1 (CH2 deformation vibration, δCH2), 1418 cm-1 (OH deformation vibration, δOH), and 1336 cm-1 (CH deformation vibration, δCH) [62]. The bands attributable to CO stretching vibration and CC stretching vibration were observed in the range of 1500–1750 cm-1 [65]. When it rose to 200 °C, the formation of carbonyl groups (acrolein, hydroxyacetone, etc.) was indicated by the bands belonging to νC O at 1637, 1647 and 1703 cm-1, along with the presence of acrolein which was confirmed by νC C band at 1653 cm-1 [62,66]. In addition, continuing to increase temperature resulted in the consumption of hydroxyl groups which could be obtained through the attenuation of δOH band, and the accumulation of products which could be observed by the increment of bands in the region 1600–1750 cm-1. The bands at 1394 cm-1 and 1605 cm-1 were attributed to symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations (νOCO) [61], respectively, indicating the occurrence of other possible reactions - generation of a small amount of acrylic acid or its esters. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we have successfully prepared unmodified and potassium-modified monolithic foam catalysts through a simple one-step annealing process. The structure, surface acidity, and surface acid sites (Brönsted and Lewis acid) of the catalysts varied with the content of K element added. When modified with 3% K, the material possessed the highest specific surface area and good stability of hierarchically porous structure, which contributed to mass transfer. The activation energy test also evidenced that the collapse of pore structure induced by excessive potassium would lead to difficulty in glycerol dehydration. Appropriate introduction of potassium can regulate the surface acid strength, surface acid amount as well as surface acid ratio of species, thus improving selectivity of acrolein and ability of anti-coking without affecting the catalytic activity. After a 10-hour run of the reaction, 3% K-BPO4 still exhibited good catalytic activity and selectivity for the main products. The above findings can provide new ideas in nanostructure regulating and surface modifying for the rational design of highly active and selective solid acid catalysts with long lifetime, but the specific reaction mechanism requires further exploration and research. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic vapor-phase dehydration of glycerol is an energy-efficient and environmentally friendly route for producing acrolein, a valuable organic chemical intermediate. However, anti-coking is one of the key problems due to the excessively acid catalytic sites and sluggish mass transfer, restricting the industrial application of this reaction. Herein, potassium element modified BPO4 monolithic foams with the hierarchically porous structure were synthesized by adding potassium element in the gel precursor of BPO4. The catalyst introducing 3% K exhibited the best acrolein selectivity of 81.0% with nearly complete glycerol conversion. In a 10-hour run of the reaction at 320 °C, the selectivity of acrolein could remain at 75.9% with 94.5% glycerol conversion, indicating the superior stability. The excellent activity and stability for 3% K-BPO4 is mainly attributed to the synergetic effect between hierarchical structure providing favorable mass transfer and appropriate acid catalytic sites inhibiting over dehydration reaction. They not only boost activity but also reduce coking, providing a unique approach for the design of solid acid catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Combining structure design and surface modification of BPO4 solid acid catalyst to boost the anti-coking performance in dehydration reaction of glycerol
